column1: This beautiful Agave is now in blossom in the garden here
column2: and I am happy to be able to send you photographs of it. This is the first time it has ever blossomed in cultivation
column3: and it has never been seen in flower in a wild state. It is a mature native-grown specimen
column6: and the leaves are arranged in spiral fashion with as much regularity as those of a screw pine. The circumference of the plant is 5 ft. 1 in.
column7: and it has 268 leaves. Its flower-stem appeared about the middle of June
column8: grew rather fast till it was 7 ft. high
column9: then rather slowly till it reached its full development. The scape is now 10 ft. 4 in. high above the plant
column10: 6½ in. in circumference at the base
column11: or 5¼ in. at a foot above the base; from there it tapers very gradually till near the apex. The flower-spike is exceedingly dense
column12: and 5 ft. 8 in. long; the lower or naked portion
column14: is prominently marked by abortive flower buds
column17: some bristle-like scales 3½ in. to 4 in. long.
